conclusion: Understand the Van der Waals Equation
The van der Waals equation of state for one mole of a real gas is given by (P + a/V^2)(V - b) = RT
Express the Equation at Critical Point Conditions
At the critical point, the volume V is equal to the critical molar volume V_c. The pressure and temperature are the critical pressure P_c and the critical temperature T_c, respectively.
Substitute P = P_c and T = T_c into the van der Waals equation: (P_c + a/V_c^2)(V_c - b) = RT_c
Rewrite the van der Waals equation in cubic form with respect to V: P_c V^3 - (RT_c + bP_c)V^2 + aV - ab = 0
At the critical point, this cubic equation should have a triple root at V = V_c. Thus, it can be written as: P_c (V - V_c)^3 = 0
Expand the Triple Root Form: P_c (V - V_c)^3 = P_c (V^3 - 3V^2 V_c + 3V V_c^2 - V_c^3)
P_c V^3 - 3P_c V^2 V_c + 3P_c V V_c^2 - P_c V_c^3 = 0
By comparing the coefficients of the expanded form with the original cubic equation P_c V^3 - (RT_c + bP_c)V^2 + aV - ab = 0, we get: -3P_c V_c = -(RT_c + bP_c), 3P_c V_c^2 = a, -P_c V_c^3 = -ab
From the first equation: 3P_c V_c = RT_c + bP_c implies bP_c = 3P_c V_c - RT_c implies b = 3V_c - RT_c/P_c
From the second equation: a = 3P_c V_c^2
From the third equation: P_c V_c^3 = ab implies P_c V_c^3 = (3P_c V_c^2)(3V_c - RT_c/P_c)
Simplify the right-hand side: P_c V_c^3 = 9P_c V_c^3 - 3RT_c V_c^2 implies 0 = 8P_c V_c^3 - 3RT_c V_c^2 implies 8P_c V_c = 3RT_c implies V_c = 3RT_c/(8P_c)
